title: How can shared knowledge shape personal knowledge? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not sure what shared knowledge is. (And maybe the definition of personal knowledge might be different to what I think it might be) It seems that shared knowledge is shared personal knowledge. If you acquire new knowledge, it gets integrated with what you already know (well, it often does, but there are quite some psychological defense mechanisms that allow you to reject or neglect new information, especially if you don’t want to change your mind).

This is social knowledge also called cultural belief. The shaping comes in the form of conditioning or brainwashing. As a child I was told many things that did not sit right with my thinking, such as the moon spun around as the earth does. Or the earth spins at 1000 k’s per hour, or is that miles per hour, either way I never believed it. You find that the human that knows or thinks differently to the rest of the clan is called a black sheep?

shared knowledge improves the knowledge of the one who shares and also the one who absorbs. the person who shares can validate his knowledge and improve it by learning something related to it. the person who absorbs will be the person who may not know what it is. So, he gets benefited by knowing it.

You must have heard that knowledge increases by sharing it with others. The evolution of knowledge began when people started sharing it with others, otherwise one person who have had knowledge about anything or everything would have died taking everything or anything with him without enlightening others.

Have you come across the theory of Just In Time Learning? It talks about how the information you find and when you find it effects what you learn and how it sticks with you…not sure if that applies to your question exactly, but should at least be interesting! The Just In Time Learning Process
